revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-15 13:25:10.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Assert that we're monkey patching before importing

This change pulls monkey patch hacks which are still relevant from
nova/__init__.py into the monkey_patch module. We also add assertions
that the 2 modules which known issues have not been imported prior to
monkey patching, which also serves as a test.

Looking at the wsgi import path I am confident the assertions in this
patch will fail in the check queue, as devstack deploys nova-api as
wsgi. This is because nova/api/openstack/__init__.py imports a whole
lot of things including (transitively) urllib3. Given that we monkey
patch in nova.api.openstack.wsgi_app, we've already loaded this stuff
before we monkey patch. To fix the wsgi case we're going to have to
monkey patch earlier. To do this we're going to have to either move
the wsgi entry point, or move monkey patching further up the tree away
from the explicit entry point, which would affect non-wsgi
deployments.

There seems to be a half-hearted desire to keep open the option of not
monkey patching, hence we monkey patch in wsgi_app and nova.cmd rather
than nova/__init__.py. If we really want to avoid top level monkey
patching I don't see any realistic option other than moving the wsgi
entry point. However, due to a few explicit uses of eventlet in the
code it might just be simpler to do it at the top level.

Extra credit: do we have anything in place to write tightly-scoped
tests for this? Neither functional or unit seem to be candidates, as
both share interpreters and functional does its own monkey patching.
With the addition of these assertions tempest is now testing this for
us as devstack deploys both wsgi and non-wsgi services, but that's not
exactly tightly scoped.

Change-Id: I52000c2ba91bf76b9e48ebf17be832ed59d79626
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Assert that we're monkey patching before importing

This change pulls monkey patch hacks which are still relevant from
nova/__init__.py into the monkey_patch module. We also add assertions
that the 2 modules which known issues have not been imported prior to
monkey patching, which also serves as a test.

Looking at the wsgi import path I am confident the assertions in this
patch will fail in the check queue, as devstack deploys nova-api as
wsgi. This is because nova/api/openstack/__init__.py imports a whole
lot of things including (transitively) urllib3. Given that we monkey
patch in nova.api.openstack.wsgi_app, we've already loaded this stuff
before we monkey patch. To fix the wsgi case we're going to have to
monkey patch earlier. To do this we're going to have to either move
the wsgi entry point, or move monkey patching further up the tree away
from the explicit entry point, which would affect non-wsgi
deployments.

There seems to be a half-hearted desire to keep open the option of not
monkey patching, hence we monkey patch in wsgi_app and nova.cmd rather
than nova/__init__.py. If we really want to avoid top level monkey
patching I don't see any realistic option other than moving the wsgi
entry point. However, due to a few explicit uses of eventlet in the
code it might just be simpler to do it at the top level.

Extra credit: do we have anything in place to write tightly-scoped
tests for this? Neither functional or unit seem to be candidates, as
both share interpreters and functional does its own monkey patching.
With the addition of these assertions tempest is now testing this for
us as devstack deploys both wsgi and non-wsgi services, but that's not
exactly tightly scoped.

Change-Id: I52000c2ba91bf76b9e48ebf17be832ed59d79626

Sometimes 'iscsiadm -m session' outputs warnings on stderr, but
still serves its purpose (usable stdout). We should not give up on
it when stderr is non-empty - instead, rely on the exit status, log
the stderr as a warning, and move on.

This change also removes 1 (ISCSI_ERR) from the list of acceptable
exit codes for the iscsiadm command, to ensure that failures get
caught.

Closes-Bug: #1732199
(cherry picked from commit d398fa82334bbabbc4c7d5b8f1fe5a7a4465200e)
"}]
commit_message:
'iscsiadm -m session' failure handling

Sometimes 'iscsiadm -m session' outputs warnings on stderr, but
still serves its purpose (usable stdout). We should not give up on
it when stderr is non-empty - instead, rely on the exit status, log
the stderr as a warning, and move on.

This change also removes 1 (ISCSI_ERR) from the list of acceptable
exit codes for the iscsiadm command, to ensure that failures get
caught.

Change-Id: Id8183cf3d8baf2f8ba6a00a47fa2ad7cc2a96aa5
Closes-Bug: #1732199
(cherry picked from commit d398fa82334bbabbc4c7d5b8f1fe5a7a4465200e)

'}, {'created': '2019-03-13 04:28:03.000000000', 'message': 'Migrate legacy jobs to Ubuntu Bionic

We have migrated the zuulv3 job to Bionic during Dec/Jan month.
 - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/000837.html
 - https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/devstack-bionic
But that effort does not move all gate job to Bionic as there are
large amount of jobs are still legacy jobs. All the legacy jobs still
use Xenial as nodeset.

As per the decided runtime for Stein, we need to test everything on openstack
CI/CD on Bionic - https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html

Below patch move the legacy base jobs to bionic which will move the derived jobs
automatically to bionic. These jobs are modified with branch variant so that they will use
Bionic node from stein onwards and xenial for all other stable branches
until stable/rocky.
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/639096

This commit remove the overridden nodeset from legacy jobs
so that it will start using the nodeset defined in parent job.

More Details: 
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/legacy-job-bionic
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003614.html

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/639096
Change-Id: Ia9e89689b4bfff8ce5fcb7c577c18b1b20e11686
'}]
commit_message:
Migrate legacy jobs to Ubuntu Bionic

We have migrated the zuulv3 job to Bionic during Dec/Jan month.
 - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/000837.html
 - https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/devstack-bionic
But that effort does not move all gate job to Bionic as there are
large amount of jobs are still legacy jobs. All the legacy jobs still
use Xenial as nodeset.

As per the decided runtime for Stein, we need to test everything on openstack
CI/CD on Bionic - https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html

Below patch move the legacy base jobs to bionic which will move the derived jobs
automatically to bionic. These jobs are modified with branch variant so that they will use
Bionic node from stein onwards and xenial for all other stable branches
until stable/rocky.
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/639096

This commit remove the overridden nodeset from legacy jobs
so that it will start using the nodeset defined in parent job.

More Details: 
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/legacy-job-bionic
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003614.html

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/639096
Change-Id: Ia9e89689b4bfff8ce5fcb7c577c18b1b20e11686

rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Id4631f16cebbfe6ebb853fcdc3b7ab23444c1233

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-16 05:18:58.000000000', 'message': 'Pass ceph_mons as a list of inventory hosts

Since change Idb9a178ca2165920804eee12a54419722aa64f51, we no longer
attempt to directly SSH to the ceph mons. Instead, we use the ansible
wait_for_connection module. One advantage to using this module is we
can pass it an ansible inventory host instead of an IP address, and
it will use the configured connection settings for that inventory
host, such as the container connection plugin.

This allows the ceph-client tasks requiring mon access to complete
without a hard dependency on an SSH connection to the mon. With this
change, we will simply pass the ceph-mon inventory hostnames to the
ceph_client role rather than a list of IP addresses.

Change-Id: Ia94ba882c2a8f568a2dcca92ee381f5833bd50af
'}]
commit_message:
Pass ceph_mons as a list of inventory hosts

Since change Idb9a178ca2165920804eee12a54419722aa64f51, we no longer
attempt to directly SSH to the ceph mons. Instead, we use the ansible
wait_for_connection module. One advantage to using this module is we
can pass it an ansible inventory host instead of an IP address, and
it will use the configured connection settings for that inventory
host, such as the container connection plugin.

This allows the ceph-client tasks requiring mon access to complete
without a hard dependency on an SSH connection to the mon. With this
change, we will simply pass the ceph-mon inventory hostnames to the
ceph_client role rather than a list of IP addresses.

Change-Id: Ia94ba882c2a8f568a2dcca92ee381f5833bd50af

commit_message:
Set Content-Type header explictly for SessionClient

SessionClient is subclassed from keystoneauth LegacyJsonAdapter.
LegacyJsonAdapter does not set the Content-Type explicitly
and results in decodeing issues in some cases.

Change-Id: Idf23022b394607c332490331fc4b216de6ff1313
Story: 2005237
Task: 30027
(cherry picked from commit bd33e310e09339a21097c66d4022538f6bcbad2f)

automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on

Change-Id: I2eea7c9f90cc08b8ae451af07259d0cf594d756a
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Run Rocky cover jobs on Xenial

The openstack-tox-cover job was updated to run on Ubuntu Bionic, but on
the stable/rocky branch we still only run python3.5 tests using Ubuntu
Xenial. This patch ensures the cover job is consistent with the other
unit tests for this branch.

Change-Id: Ife72b2351bbe0f94f5aa8278bf4dc5d0746a882d

subject: WIP - LOSF
messages:
[{'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-06-01 15:24:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-06-01 15:45:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Work in progress to make kvfile.py much smaller by making classes inherit from diskfile's.
The few changes to diskfile/replicator/reconstructor would go to a separate patch. 
The patch includes generated grpc/protobuf code"}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-06-06 12:29:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-06-07 08:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

As suggested, we can discuss the design here:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/LOSF_Questions'}, {'account_id': 11950, 'date': '2018-10-30 06:32:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm very interested in this feature.
Now I'm testing Swift behavior with this patch but I found a couple of issues.

I tried LOSF using this patch set 2.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/571763/2

Following the procedures described in README.LOSF in the patch set 2, but 503 errors occurred by download of an object.
I checked the log message and found that there is not enough argument to open() in diskfile.py.
The log message is as follows::
http://paste.openstack.org/show/733606/

After uploading the object, an error occurred in self.open().
http://paste.openstack.org/show/733607/

When I download the object again after correcting the argument of open() of diskfile.py, another error occurred around grpc call.
http://paste.openstack.org/show/733608/

Do you know anything about the errors?"}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-10-30 14:40:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If that's possible for you, the easiest way to test LOSF is to use vagrant with VirtualBox:

git clone -b losf-v2.18.0 https://github.com/alecuyer/vagrant-swift-all-in-one.git
cd vagrant-swift-all-in-one
vagrant up
vagrant ssh

This will create a working SAIO for you to test LOSF, based on swift version 2.18.0

About the errors you saw: the first one (not enough arguments to open()) is likely because the patch was applied against a version of swift that is not 2.18.0

The second message happens because a check needs to run when the key-value store is first created. This is done automatically in the SAIO setup when you start the rpc service (swift-init object-rpcmanager start).
The script that actually runs the check is bin/volume_check.py

Feel free to email me, if I can help with the tests, alexandre.lecuyer@corp.ovh.com"}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2019-03-18 15:45:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
WIP - LOSF

Adds a diskfile implementation which stores data in large files, rather than in
individual files. This is useful if you expect to store a large amount of small
objects.

See README.LOSF for how to get it running on SAIO.

This is work in progress.

Change-Id: I7d04443e78c968c2bfb67085ef6e2c30f73b3ef8

commit_message:
Fix tox cover environment on python 3.6

In python 3.6, os.path.join does not accept Mock objects, giving the
following error:

TypeError: expected str, bytes or os.PathLike object, not MagicMock

Since the switch to use ubuntu bionic for the base image for jobs,
python 3.6 is the default for python 3.

Change-Id: I79bec585361a54b8303c130a363c62d9a4b7faae
Story: 2004959
Task: 30035

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7c2941c93df76e3710bec90d724de7f1913e0f7e

commit_message:
Create commands for configuring BIOS on given nodes

This commit introduces two new commands to configure BIOS:

1) openstack overcloud node bios configure --configuration <..> [--all-manageable|uuid1,uuid2,..]
2) openstack overcloud node bios reset [--all-manageable|uuid1,uuid2,..]

The first command applys BIOS configuration on given nodes or all manageable nodes;
the second command resets BIOS configuration to factory default on given nodes or all manageable nodes;

Depends-On: Icdaa734a44c55c830c0109d25488b68838e8736f
Change-Id: I809883e0e54a66bca58a0e45c035c69bcc39dcd1

For list, it doesn't work. The api is not returning the health status on list. For status reason it works. But, didn't we discussed that by default the health_status_reason won't be shown and a new param will be added? like --detailed"}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-03-04 10:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-03-04 17:25:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi @Spyros, you're right. 

For cluster list, we need this patch https://review.openstack.org/640222 first.

For cluster show, I changed my mind when I did the testing. I'm putting the 'health_status_reason' at the bottom, and with --fit-width. The table format still looks well. And most important, as we discussed, the API has returned everything, we can just show it without another API call.

But I'm open mind, if you still think a --detailed is necessary, I'm happy to add it.

subject: Remove PXE filter logging
messages:
[{'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2019-03-15 01:11:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-03-15 01:42:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd prefer to keep it as debug level, it doesn't harm anyone, you can easily filter it out with proper keyword."}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2019-03-15 13:05:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I'd prefer to keep it as debug level, it doesn't harm anyone, you
 > can easily filter it out with proper keyword.

The issue is that the debug log is filled with "fsm_reset_on_error" messages which generates questions from customers etc.  If we want to keep these the message can be changed so it doesn't include "error".'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-03-16 14:04:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

recheck

Warmly agree. I keep getting questions from people who grepped for "error" and saw these lines. They used to be pretty helpful when we just introduced the new filter and had to debug it. But now I agree that they're too low-level (I wish we had a TRACE level).'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-03-18 01:45:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

understood, the word "customer" explains everything..
I tend to believe removing debug log doesn't need a release note, but anyway.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-03-18 10:13:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}]

Change-Id: Ib848a13f30f5ef0074c9e43eb0a414bec0254637
'}]
commit_message:
Remove PXE filter logging

Remove log messages which tend to fill up the inspector logs when
debug is enabled without providing much value.

Change-Id: Ib848a13f30f5ef0074c9e43eb0a414bec0254637

[{'created': '2019-03-11 05:02:36.000000000', 'message': 'Fix the signature ordering issues

Change-Id: I6daffdb49a1f31e3b088ad5038a3baa12f5392ef
'}, {'created': '2019-03-12 05:07:42.000000000', 'message': "Fix the signature ordering issues

This signature order changed because from ironic driver
(ironic/drivers/modules/drac/raid.py) in def commit_config()
we are sending arguments to commit_pending_raid_changes
(raid_controller, reboot, realtime) and in draclient's client.py
taking arguments as def commit_pending_raid_changes
(self, raid_controller, reboot=False, start_time='TIME_NOW',
realtime=False)
so, in this case, realtime value assigned to start_time variable,
which is incorrect, so we have changed signature order by swapping
place of start_time and realtime arguments.

Change-Id: I6daffdb49a1f31e3b088ad5038a3baa12f5392ef
"}]
commit_message:
Fix the signature ordering issues

This signature order changed because from ironic driver
(ironic/drivers/modules/drac/raid.py) in def commit_config()
we are sending arguments to commit_pending_raid_changes
(raid_controller, reboot, realtime) and in draclient's client.py
taking arguments as def commit_pending_raid_changes
(self, raid_controller, reboot=False, start_time='TIME_NOW',
realtime=False)
so, in this case, realtime value assigned to start_time variable,
which is incorrect, so we have changed signature order by swapping
place of start_time and realtime arguments.

Change-Id: I6daffdb49a1f31e3b088ad5038a3baa12f5392ef

commit_message:
Set Content-Type header explictly for SessionClient

SessionClient is subclassed from keystoneauth LegacyJsonAdapter.
LegacyJsonAdapter does not set the Content-Type explicitly
and results in decodeing issues in some cases.

Change-Id: Idf23022b394607c332490331fc4b216de6ff1313
Story: 2005237
Task: 30027
(cherry picked from commit bd33e310e09339a21097c66d4022538f6bcbad2f)

commit_message:
Accept hostname in reserve_node in addition to provision_node

With the allocation API we will need to provide the hostname as
the allocation name. Thus, we have to do it earlier.

Change-Id: I8afd8af23ad929fd9768e95a82fecd114fdcbfd9

commit_message:
Implement VNF monitoring using Mistral

- Refactor mistral code
- Add workflow and plugin request for VNF monitoring
- Call policy action in tacker conductor

Co-Authored-By: Nguyen Hai <nguyentrihai93@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Yong sheng gong <gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net>
Co-Authored-By: lijiale <lijiale@cmss.chinamobile.com>
Change-Id: If3dba64ee1d67106d15d7f2b841d42ca4286edac
Implements: blueprint mistral-monitor-policy

subject: fix tox python3 overrides

[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-29 23:54:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Wish I could give this a +2'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:12:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also note, this repo is close to abandoned, as the telemetry-specs have received no spec changes in approximately the last 2 years.'}, {'account_id': 28543, 'date': '2019-03-13 03:28:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27078, 'date': '2019-03-13 07:16:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-18 13:13:19.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003693.html'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-03-18 14:43:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It is a shame this is being abandoned, but http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-telemetry/%23openstack-telemetry.2019-03-11.log.html points out that telemetry-specs is no longer used.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-29 23:54:12.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: If2b62ddff24269933481f571822955f936f5e3ee
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: If2b62ddff24269933481f571822955f936f5e3ee
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Create stable/stein branches for all libraries

Create stable/stein branches for all libraries and client libraries
that do not have them already. The branching point is the most
recent library release.

NB: ironic-lib, kuryr, metalsmith, octavia-lib, python-saharaclient,
python-zunclient and sushy already had stable/stein branches defined.

Change-Id: I2c584e497fb9fc21b3e0f580657b486672608d1e

commit_message:
heatlh_manager default to os_workers

health_manager has switched from spawning threads to processes. We
should have it follow the os_worker calculation.

Change-Id: I3abab863b210dcc6a75b70f9c14edb17e1713a97

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-07 17:40:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix build all upper-constraints wheels w/ py3.6

zVMCloudConnector wheel cannot be built on python3.6
with a version below 1.0.0. Yet, the global-requirements
would allow to try building wheels for lower versions
than 1.0.0.

This is a problem, as LOCI project builds wheels for all the
packages in upper-constraints, and then consumes those when
installing projects. For those with python3.6, this would cause
a failure to build wheels, and an inability to consume those
wheels.

The problem does not appear on Rocky, as the
minimum version has been bumped there for python3.6 already.

This fixes it by conditionally bumping the version for
zVMCloudConnector on the python version.

Notes:
- Projects consuming zVMCloudConnector in Queens probably
  will not be interested in bumping their version of
  zVMCloudConnector for python3.6, therefore the fix should come
  from consuming projects/requirements.
- Bumping this version merely allows buildability of the wheels,
  not that the project will work with python3.6. For that,
  the necessary patches have to be applied, and a bigger bump is
  required. However, I consider running software for python3.6 is
  a completely different project in itself than this patch.

Change-Id: Iae4ec550de101648ff9c8d1b743ccaa285bd0033
'}, {'created': '2019-03-07 18:38:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix build all upper-constraints wheels w/ py3.6

with a version below 1.0.0. Yet, the global-requirements
would allow to try building wheels for lower versions
than 1.0.0.

packages in upper-constraints, and then consumes those when

wheels.

The problem does not appear on Rocky, as the
minimum version has been bumped there for python3.6 already.

This fixes it by conditionally updating the minimum version
zVMCloudConnector depending on the python version.

Notes:
- Projects consuming zVMCloudConnector in Queens probably
  will not be interested in bumping their version of
  zVMCloudConnector for python3.6, therefore the fix should come
  from consuming projects/requirements.
- Bumping this version merely allows buildability of the wheels,
  not that the project needs to work with python3.6. For that,
  the necessary patches have to be applied, and a bigger bump is
  required. However, I consider running software for python3.6 is
  a completely different project in itself than this patch.

Change-Id: Iae4ec550de101648ff9c8d1b743ccaa285bd0033
'}]
commit_message:
Fix build all upper-constraints wheels w/ py3.6

zVMCloudConnector wheel cannot be built on python3.6
with a version below 1.0.0. Yet, the global-requirements
would allow to try building wheels for lower versions
than 1.0.0.

This is a problem, as LOCI project builds wheels for all the
packages in upper-constraints, and then consumes those when
installing projects. For those with python3.6, this would cause
a failure to build wheels, and an inability to consume those
wheels.

The problem does not appear on Rocky, as the
minimum version has been bumped there for python3.6 already.

This fixes it by conditionally updating the minimum version
zVMCloudConnector depending on the python version.

Notes:
- Projects consuming zVMCloudConnector in Queens probably
  will not be interested in bumping their version of
  zVMCloudConnector for python3.6, therefore the fix should come
  from consuming projects/requirements.
- Bumping this version merely allows buildability of the wheels,
  not that the project needs to work with python3.6. For that,
  the necessary patches have to be applied, and a bigger bump is
  required. However, I consider running software for python3.6 is
  a completely different project in itself than this patch.

Change-Id: Iae4ec550de101648ff9c8d1b743ccaa285bd0033

commit_message:
Add a job to run full Tempest with enabled profiler

Default Tempest jobs only execute tests, but do not configure
osprofiler library. This patch adds a job that executes full
Tempest with enabled osprofiler. Currently the job is non-voting.

Depends-on: I64f30c36adbf7fb26609142f22d3e305ac9e82b5
Change-Id: Ib0ad4d22b62dba7cfea76283be2d87574f010c87

commit_message:
Expose instance reservation affinity support

For instance reservation, blazar has checked the affinity policy and
raised an exception if it is None or True. Since we are now ready to
support affinity=None/True, this patch deletes the check and adds a
migration script to accept a NULL value for the affinity column in the
database.

This patch also updates the CLI usage document of the instance
reservation and adds the release note for the instance reservation
affinity policy.

Change-Id: Icf26d1b7dffe64f82d7084dcebb5df1c7c9f106d
Closes-Bug: #1737676
Blueprint: no-affinity-instance-reservation

commit_message:
Fix OOB introspection to use pxe_enabled flag in idrac driver

Baremetal nodes fail to pxe boot during OpenStack deployment.
Reason of this failure is because we are not checking the
actual pxe device interface and updating the port pxe_enabled field.

This patch make sure that everytime when port is created, it checks the
the BIOS and UEFI boot modes of node and fetch the pxe device interfaces
values matching to nic id and then update the port's pxe_enabled field.

Change-Id: I2890bf16110b713e269d4a4fe410f57273dc8e83
Story: 2004340
(cherry picked from commit 2b74d940c932c1bb4498f47372c0545e4480799f)

commit_message:
Bump minimum oslo.log version

versionutils.deprecated.ROCKY was not introduced until 3.38.0 of
oslo.log, so the stable/rocky branch needs that as a minimum. Proposing
directly to stable/rocky branch because master has already raised the
minimum.

Change-Id: I8300a57379feec8497ccc09f7686b411835c6694
Closes-bug: #1793347

commit_message:
Fix YAML code execution issue

There is an issue with the default YAML loader, which allows arbitrary
code execution, as documented here:
https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/wiki/PyYAML-yaml.load(input)-Deprecation.

This can be avoided by using yaml.safe_load. We don't require Python
object serialisation, so safe_load is sufficient.

Change-Id: I09190766066ab56d04b1317a4022782160d60528
Story: 2005253
Task: 30050

commit_message:
setup: allow custom conductor host

This patch allows using a custom conductor host to do all the
deployment and setup steps when installing a brand new compute
node such as adding cell mappings, etc.

Change-Id: I61fc92d17d32e367ac133000d06bc83358735312

Deploy Templates: factor out ironic.conductor.steps

There is enough steps code in conductor.utils to warrant a separate
module.

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Iadd5a805729e07d8e61416e802246f8f3cd97d22
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
switch documentation job to new PTI

This is a mechanically generated patch to switch the documentation
jobs to use the new PTI versions of the jobs as part of the
python3-first goal.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Ibad587f3e5805cf33234eea67063f02eafe153f0
Story: #2002586
Task: #24285

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Co-Authored-By: Dharmendra Kushwaha <dharmendra.kushwaha@india.nec.com>
Co-Authored-By: Nguyen Hai <nguyentrihai93@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Iedbab108a97d5d73b2703c54ea7d40569b8b8701
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Update master for stable/stein

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/stein.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

Change-Id: I1404c575b0fc5aeae282ad6ee5f0ea5a205b3aa4
Sem-Ver: feature

subject: Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein
messages: [{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-18 13:05:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-18 13:02:12.000000000', 'message': 'Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I756fd7c99e4898fe2fcec37e9d28cb057690f8a1
'}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I756fd7c99e4898fe2fcec37e9d28cb057690f8a1

commit_message:
Switch to use stestr for unit test

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
So we should switch to stestr.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: I33e075b3b7f2eec889cd1698edaab5ee89f69121

We need to change the package name of uwsgi-plugin-python to

commit_message:
Change uwsgi-plugin-python to uwsgi-plugin-python2

We need to change the package name of uwsgi-plugin-python to
uwsgi-plugin-python2 in Redhat Family OS, because they do not have
the name of the package.

Change-Id: I459ea1f300e1d203e77dfc739ff446ca985aacb1

commit_message:
Change tripleo job to multinode-containers job

Standalone 003 jobs seems like doesn't cover mistral functionality
let's use multinode-containers for that.

Change-Id: I068e20ab8fe9b0dcae5972d14fbe6700aa3e35bf

commit_message:
k8s_fedora: Add ca_key before all deployments

The script [1] that writes the ca.key depends in the apiserver to be
running and the script to start the apiserver [0] needs the ca.key to
exist.

Write the ca_key before all other scripts that depend on the apiserver.

story: 2005254
task: 30051

[0]
https://github.com/openstack/magnum/blob/master/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/enable-services-master.sh
[1]
https://github.com/openstack/magnum/blob/master/magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_atomic_v1/templates/kubecluster.yaml#L843

Change-Id: If532ccc4673225eb1b7e7cab77a30950ee5ee695
Signed-off-by: Spyros Trigazis <spyridon.trigazis@cern.ch>

commit_message:
Check pep8 without ignoring D000

Currently, pep8 ignores D000 check because of error:
"D000 Cannot analyze code. Pygments package not found."

Pygments is supported from:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568729/

Change-Id: Icfd23b83d73dee89a71c92f1f787bb3791fd460e

commit_message:
Adds doc8 check to pep8

This patch adds doc8 check for .rst files to pep8.
Files that fail doc8 check are also fixed.

Ignores D001 of doc8 check. This requires lot of changes and
should be done in a separated patch.

commit_message:
Enable authtoken cache

For the undercloud we can specify memcache that can be shared by all the
services. Additionally because we need to still allow folks to configure
UndercloudExtraConfig we set it to deep_merge

Change-Id: I07f9a8e9c454a5e41d0a8b766d5d754f63126b90
Closes-Bug: #1820342

commit_message:
Switch to using ``ceph.conf`` template from charm-helpers

The Glance charm distributes a out of date ``ceph.conf`` template
that among other things does not contain the ``rbd_features``
configuration.

Switch to using the tempalte distributed with ``charm-helpers``

The effective diff between the two can be viewed here:
https://gist.github.com/fnordahl/a4034999cec28fd70628599125b10bda

Change-Id: I94f5a80c6ebfefdf7196cdf533f76931cfb22950

commit_message:
Adds doc8 check to pep8

This patch adds doc8 check for .rst files to pep8.
Files that fail doc8 check are also fixed.

Ignores D001 of doc8 check. This requires lot of changes and
should be done in a separated patch.

Change-Id: Ideaa3c6280e807026ce46302abcf0e7e569dbdbd

subject: Reuse common get_providers_with_resource()
messages:
[{'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-03-17 06:25:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-17 16:31:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Love this.

If we were doing this on an operation that had the potential to loop a zillion times, it might warrant closer evaluation for performance degradation. But we're iterating over the number of resources requested in a single GET /resource_providers, which should almost always be quite a small number.

Good stuff, Tetsuro."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-18 09:54:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Yeah, nice. If `resources` where ever super complex this could be an issue, but as things stand this is more clear.

At some point we probably want to do a detailed analysis of our sql queries and the surrounding set manipulation. There are probably plenty of ways we can improve both readability and efficiency.'}]

'}]
commit_message:
Reuse common get_providers_with_resource()

This patch refactors _get_all_by_filters_from_db() function used in
`GET /resource_providers` to use more common function,
get_providers_with_resource().

SQL queries will increase slightly by this patch, but it is done
for the readability and the debuggability.

Change-Id: Iff0cec9445e6ddafa37c852438ce0c54fef77082

[{'created': '2019-03-15 10:17:50.000000000', 'message': 'Enable ipv6_forwarding in HA router's namespace

When HA router is created in "stanby" mode, ipv6 forwarding is
disabled by default in its namespace.
But when router is transitioned to be "master" on node, ipv6
forwarding should be enabled. This was fine for routers with
configured gateway but we somehow missed the case when router don't
have gateway configured.
Because of that missing ipv6 forwarding setting in such case, IPv6
W-E traffic between 2 subnets was not working fine in L3 HA case.

This patch fixes it by adding configuring ipv6_forwarding on
"all" interface in router's namespace always, even if it don't have
gateway configured.

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/framework.py

Change-Id: I8b1b2b426f7a26a4b2407a83f9bf29dd6e9ba7b0

commit_message:
Enable ipv6_forwarding in HA router's namespace

When HA router is created in "stanby" mode, ipv6 forwarding is
disabled by default in its namespace.
But when router is transitioned to be "master" on node, ipv6
forwarding should be enabled. This was fine for routers with
configured gateway but we somehow missed the case when router don't
have gateway configured.
Because of that missing ipv6 forwarding setting in such case, IPv6
W-E traffic between 2 subnets was not working fine in L3 HA case.

This patch fixes it by adding configuring ipv6_forwarding on
"all" interface in router's namespace always, even if it don't have
gateway configured.

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/framework.py

Change-Id: I8b1b2b426f7a26a4b2407a83f9bf29dd6e9ba7b0
CLoses-Bug: #1818224
(cherry picked from commit b119247bea89aec5604e7ac61675aed240195931)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-20 20:34:51.000000000', 'message': "Switch Octavia API calls to openstacksdk

For a while we were using a dirty hack to call Octavia API - i.e.  we
were mocking python-neutronclient to use a session pointing to Octavia
endpoint. This was a workaround to save some effort that was needed to
introduce python-octaviaclient dependency.

As Kuryr is strongly tied to Kubernetes version it is serving, we should
try to limit its dependency on OpenStack versions. E.g. we should be
able to cooperate with various versions of Octavia. openstacksdk is a
tool that is designed to do exactly that, adding abstraction layer that
hides differences between APIs and as last resort allowing doing bare
HTTP calls, while taking care of all the Keystone stuff for us.

This commit removes the ugly workaround mentioned in first paragraph and
switches all the LBaaS v2 calls to use openstacksdk's Octavia proxy.

Implements: blueprint switch-to-openstacksdk
Change-Id: Ic0bb56f90fe9effcdcb2ae5db96b8a1ec19738df

Also some leftovers from LBaaS v2 removal are cleaned up, e.g. logic
behind not using cascade deletion or workaround for LbaaS v2 issues with
pools.

Implements: blueprint switch-to-openstacksdk
Change-Id: Ic0bb56f90fe9effcdcb2ae5db96b8a1ec19738df

commit_message:
Switch Octavia API calls to openstacksdk

For a while we were using a dirty hack to call Octavia API - i.e.  we
were mocking python-neutronclient to use a session pointing to Octavia
endpoint. This was a workaround to save some effort that was needed to
introduce python-octaviaclient dependency.

As Kuryr is strongly tied to Kubernetes version it is serving, we should
try to limit its dependency on OpenStack versions. E.g. we should be
able to cooperate with various versions of Octavia. openstacksdk is a
tool that is designed to do exactly that, adding abstraction layer that
hides differences between APIs and as last resort allowing doing bare
HTTP calls, while taking care of all the Keystone stuff for us.

This commit removes the ugly workaround mentioned in first paragraph and
switches all the LBaaS v2 calls to use openstacksdk's Octavia proxy.
Also some leftovers from LBaaS v2 removal are cleaned up, e.g. logic
behind not using cascade deletion or workaround for LbaaS v2 issues with
pools.

Implements: blueprint switch-to-openstacksdk

commit_message:
Consider affinity=True in reallocation

When a failed host is detected, blazar reallocates the reservation to
another host. But since the reallocation logic's granularity was not
per reservation but per allocation, it reallocated the reservation to
different hosts even if the affinity rule is set to True.

This patch changes the reallocation logic's granularity from per
allocation to per reservation and consider affinity=True cases.

Change-Id: I18d49fb994291d972216cd4c652b31e82c444c66
Blueprint: no-affinity-instance-reservation

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Unmanage Snapshot Improvements

This change removes an expensive and unnecessary call in the
unmanage snapshot operation.  An additional log warning has
also been added to notify users of the inability to delete
volumes where a linked snapshot has been unmanaged but still
existsX on the back end storage array.

Change-Id: I77720dc8e3b3c79e60d0ea16939a80480067215e

[{'created': '2019-03-15 02:45:14.000000000', 'message': 'Pass kwargs to exception to get better format of error message

If we do not pass kwargs to exception, the parameter will be deemed
as message and msg_fmt is ignored, so the message will be displayed
directly. This is to pass kwargs to some exceptions, to get better
format of error message.

Change-Id: I66677a90430d9e6699619539cb8f575f57b19433
'}]
commit_message:
Pass kwargs to exception to get better format of error message

If we do not pass kwargs to exception, the parameter will be deemed
as message and msg_fmt is ignored, so the message will be displayed
directly. This is to pass kwargs to some exceptions, to get better
format of error message.

Change-Id: I66677a90430d9e6699619539cb8f575f57b19433

[{'created': '2019-03-08 20:34:22.000000000', 'message': "Better handle ports in security groups

After taking a closer look at bug 1818385, I found a couple
of follow-on things to fix in the security group code.

First, there are very few protocols that accept ports,
especially via iptables.  For this reason I think it's
acceptable that the API rejects them as invalid.

Second, UDPlite has some interesting support in iptables.  It
does not support using --dport directly, but does using
'-m multiport --dports 123', and also supports port ranges using
'-m multiport --dports 123:124'.  Added code for this special
case.

Change-Id: Ifb2e6bb6c7a2e2987ba95040ef5a98ed50aa36d4
Closes-Bug: #1818385

commit_message:
Better handle ports in security groups

After taking a closer look at bug 1818385, I found a couple
of follow-on things to fix in the security group code.

First, there are very few protocols that accept ports,
especially via iptables.  For this reason I think it's
acceptable that the API rejects them as invalid.

Second, UDPlite has some interesting support in iptables.  It
does not support using --dport directly, but does using
'-m multiport --dports 123', and also supports port ranges using
'-m multiport --dports 123:124'.  Added code for this special
case.

Change-Id: Ifb2e6bb6c7a2e2987ba95040ef5a98ed50aa36d4
Closes-Bug: #1818385

subject: [Documentation] Fix links releases.
messages:
[{'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-01-21 16:04:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-01-21 16:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-01-22 09:48:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-01-22 09:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-01-22 14:22:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

These references are just examples that will constantly be changing. I do not think we need to continuously update these every release.'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-01-22 15:32:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-01-22 15:35:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I disagree, it's important to fix the name, because we have also links. However we can use fake name like tango all over, except when we have links."}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-01-23 20:07:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

What do you think about my previous answer?'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-01-23 21:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think we either leave the older links as examples, or we rework this to not be something that someone needs to remember to update every single cycle.'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-01-24 13:15:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think I have an solution to have a dynamic value for the version. I'm going to modify the patch."}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-02-13 13:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-02-13 14:04:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I really don't think we should require making HTTP requests out to a site (that could potentially be offline) when building docs.

I still think we should just leave static data as an example in these docs and not worry about continually updating it or making it dynamic."}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-02-13 14:52:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I really don't think we should require making HTTP requests out to
 > a site (that could potentially be offline) when building docs.
 > 
 > I still think we should just leave static data as an example in
 > these docs and not worry about continually updating it or making it
 > dynamic.

I guess we can't consider the probability that the site will be down versus the time to manage responses to users and customers support about a documentation non up-to-date.

Site down can be easily detected and I suppose we can also easily detect CI who fail during documentation building due to site down.

IMHO these changes are not an earthquake and can save us to spend time to update this kind of stuff.

We need to consider first plausibility versus probability."}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-03-01 10:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Just to be sure, you continue to disagree? To know if I must abandoned the patch.'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-03-18 10:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

After more two weeks without answer, I suppose that mean you disagree.'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-03-18 10:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

The team disagree.'}]

commit_message:
Run jobs under python2 and python3

-Switch functional job to run under python3
-Create a functional job to run under python2
-Create a tempest job to run under python2
-Create tox env to run functional tests under python3
-Validate if `USE_PYTHON3` is set to `True` to call
the correct env for tests
-Remove hardcoded path for client when running functional tests
- Update tests failures to work for python2 and python3

Change-Id: I55abc999f6f397b171d05fd9e9b39d833ca95e55

I think it's wrong way of doing this. Escalating monasca-agent itself to root level is bad idea. Something like this should be done by operator himself so that he know what and where is happening. If someone get access to monasca-agent on such system he could easily change its code and run it as a root on the system and operator would have no idea what happened.
I think better documentation is needed and maybe monasca-setup script should warn when there is no access to this data."}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2019-03-18 09:58:40.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Do not execute event of transitional lease

If the continuous execution of an event is called just after the lease
creation is called, it can fail with the invalid lease status
transition error from CREATING to STARTING.

This patch adds a check before the event execution whether the lease
status of the event is not transitional but stable and pend the
execution to the next time if it is transitional.

Change-Id: I033dd814d384131de8e7494d22cd42f1ea67112b
Closes-Bug: #1820476

commit_message:
Deprecate `personality` for `OS::Nova::Server`

This patch deprecate personality property for `OS::Nova::Server`.
Since that property is deprecated by nova since version 2.57,
we should plan to Hidden that property soon.
please use ``user_data`` or ``metadata`` instead. If that
property really required, use config ``max_nova_api_microversion``
to set the maximum nova API microversion <2.57 for nova client
plugin to support personality property.

Add config option ``max_nova_api_microversion`` to set the maximum
nova API microversion for nova client plugin.

Story: #2004188
Task: #29979

Change-Id: I1852739e818ec67ac5a821e436e243eaa72f0938

"}, {'created': '2019-03-13 19:59:43.000000000', 'message': "Add option to deploy coredns

As a step to improve testing capabilities of our gates, this commit
enhances DevStack with support for deploying coredns in our K8s cluster.
The idea here is to be able to run any tests that are referring to
services by <namespace>.<service-name>, in particular upstream K8s
tests.

The tricky part here is that on gate VM's an instance of unbound DNS is
running on 127.0.0.1:53. As in DevStack-deployed Kuryr pods doesn't
support IPv6, we couldn't just take IPv6 addresses of upstream DNS from
unbound configuration and use them in coredns pods. Instead the coredns
instance is running on host networking and binds to $HOST_IP:53, which
is also used as value of kubelet's --cluster-dns option, while
forwarding any upstream DNS requests to the local unbound instance. This
isn't perfectly how it would be set up in production environment, but
should be close enough for our purposes.

This change only affects DevStack, so it's completely safe from release
point of view.

Change-Id: Icdab52a6229b2209f58e26e4d885f551883727b5
Partial-Implements: blueprint k8s-upstream-tests
"}, {'created': '2019-03-14 11:56:02.000000000', 'message': "Add option to deploy coredns

isn't perfectly how it would be set up in production environment, but
should be close enough for our purposes.

This change only affects DevStack, so it's completely safe from release
point of view. coredns gets enabled only on gates running Kubernetes as
OpenShift gates run openshift-dns already.

Change-Id: Icdab52a6229b2209f58e26e4d885f551883727b5

commit_message:
Add option to deploy coredns

As a step to improve testing capabilities of our gates, this commit
enhances DevStack with support for deploying coredns in our K8s cluster.
The idea here is to be able to run any tests that are referring to
services by <namespace>.<service-name>, in particular upstream K8s
tests.

The tricky part here is that on gate VM's an instance of unbound DNS is
running on 127.0.0.1:53. As in DevStack-deployed Kuryr pods doesn't
support IPv6, we couldn't just take IPv6 addresses of upstream DNS from
unbound configuration and use them in coredns pods. Instead the coredns
instance is running on host networking and binds to $HOST_IP:53, which
is also used as value of kubelet's --cluster-dns option, while
forwarding any upstream DNS requests to the local unbound instance. This
isn't perfectly how it would be set up in production environment, but
should be close enough for our purposes.

This change only affects DevStack, so it's completely safe from release
point of view. coredns gets enabled only on gates running Kubernetes as
OpenShift gates run openshift-dns already.

Change-Id: Icdab52a6229b2209f58e26e4d885f551883727b5
Partial-Implements: blueprint k8s-upstream-tests

[{'account_id': 26571, 'date': '2019-03-12 08:14:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-03-12 10:11:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Could not import extension sphinxcontrib.apidoc (exception: No module named apidoc)'}, {'account_id': 26571, 'date': '2019-03-13 07:47:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I checked all the code, didn't find a reference to sphinxcontrib.apidoc.I have some confusion about solving this problem."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-13 09:14:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I checked all the code, didn't find a reference to
 > sphinxcontrib.apidoc.I have some confusion about solving this
 > problem.

The library has a dependency on sphinxcontrib-apidoc for building the documentation:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/python-mistralclient/tree/doc/requirements.txt#n7

Which means you need to add 

 BuildRequires:  {{ py2pkg('sphinxcontrib-apidoc') }}

to the build dependencies so that when the docs are built, the module is available to import."}, {'account_id': 26571, 'date': '2019-03-13 14:47:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26571, 'date': '2019-03-13 14:51:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Do you plan to address the CI issues?

http://logs.openstack.org/84/642684/3/check/openstack-tox-linters/70ea2da/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-03-13_15_14_03_780472

The builds are failing because the library changed the way it builds its docs, example:

https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/home:suse-cloud-ci:rpm-packaging-sles12-Master-b0bde9d4caa8df5216964b03c939934706a2fc95/python-mistralclient/standard/x86_64

You need to use the sphinx-build command instead of the setuptools invocation, for example like this:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/rpm-packaging/tree/openstack/python-neutronclient/python-neutronclient.spec.j2#n89

but better to use PBR_VERSION=%{version} in this case'}, {'account_id': 26571, 'date': '2019-03-15 01:52:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-03-09 06:40:33.000000000', 'message': 'split host_state.least_disk_mb out of free_disk_mb

Resource tracker consumes compute_node.free_disk_gb, but scheduler
consumes host_state.free_disk_mb, which comes from the min value of
compute_node.free_disk_gb and compute_node.disk_available_least. This
causes resource inconsistency between scheduler cache and compute
service resource view within a small period. Thus the consequence of
this bug is not very explicit because host_state are refreshed from
compute_node very frequently.

This patch corrects the inconsistent resource consumption in scheduler
side. It is a prerequisite of future schedulers such as
resource-provider scheduler and shared-state scheduler. They requires
the consistent resource consumption between schedulers and compute
nodes.

Closes-Bug: #1420102
Related to blueprint resource-providers-scheduler

compute_node.free_disk_gb and compute_node.disk_available_least. This

commit_message:
split host_state.least_disk_mb out of free_disk_mb

Resource tracker consumes compute_node.free_disk_gb, but scheduler
consumes host_state.free_disk_mb, which comes from the min value of
compute_node.free_disk_gb and compute_node.disk_available_least. This
inconsistent consumption causes inconsistent available resource
identification between scheduler and compute resource trackers.
However, the symptom is mild because scheduler cache is refreshed
frequently, and RT's claim is authoritative during instance placement in
compute nodes.

This patch corrects the inconsistent resource consumption in scheduler
side.

Closes-Bug: #1550098
Change-Id: I2657ea871ac962a07b28d653ef559ad738e03ccb

commit_message:
Armada: Fix openstack-helm update password job

The armada update password job was attempting to invoke a script
that didn't exist for sourcing the passwords. This updates the
path appropriately

Change-Id: Ieb0b85c18ed4f2a589ee3a3ba251317350dc4b81

commit_message:
WIP: Use the docker_image_tag instead of build id unless mixed upgrade

This patch is on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/642420/

Please compare this review to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/643187/
To figure out which direction we'd like to go.

Related-Bug: 1819583

Looks like we only bump SG quotas when running with "namespace" SG

Closes-Bug: 1820284
'}]
commit_message:
DevStack: Bump SG quotas for "policy" SG driver

Looks like we only bump SG quotas when running with "namespace" SG
driver. This commit adds the same behavior for "policy" driver.

Change-Id: Id257bd0a1b5dfe847eb9769568b4e9cdbece0906
Closes-Bug: 1820284

subject: Drop py35 jobs
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-12 10:14:35.000000000', 'message': 'Drop py35 jobs

Python 3.5 was the target runtime for the Rocky release. The current
target py3 runtime for Stein is Python 3.6, so there is no reason to
keep testing against the older version.

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html#python-runtime-for-stein

Change-Id: I93d11fce8c51ed7b8b8ac65413a2b0b399be5e5e
'}]
commit_message:
Drop py35 jobs

Python 3.5 was the target runtime for the Rocky release. The current
target py3 runtime for Stein is Python 3.6, so there is no reason to
keep testing against the older version.

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html#python-runtime-for-stein

Change-Id: I93d11fce8c51ed7b8b8ac65413a2b0b399be5e5e

commit_message:
Add support SFC encapsulation from networking-sfc

This feature allows choosing SFC encapsulation between MPLS
and NSH (default MPLS). It also apply SFC proxy to make use
of correlation.

Change-Id: Ia5eda02df415c9e3f6f035068176d60a14ffb68f

commit_message:
Migrate tacker legacy jobs to Ubuntu Bionic

We have migrated the zuulv3 job to Bionic during Dec/Jan month.
 - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/000837.html
 - https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/devstack-bionic
But that effort does not move all gate job to Bionic as there are
large amount of jobs are still legacy jobs. All the legacy jobs still
use Xenial as nodeset.

As per the decided runtime for Stein, we need to test everything on openstack
CI/CD on Bionic - https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html

Below patch move the legacy base jobs to bionic which will move the derived jobs
automatically to bionic. These jobs are modified with branch variant so that they will use
Bionic node from stein onwards and xenial for all other stable branches
until stable/rocky.
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/639096

This commit modify the nodeset from xenial to bionic which will migrate
the tacker mutinode jobs to bionic.

More Details: 
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/legacy-job-bionic
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003614.html

Change-Id: Ic83d18bbbbaa86750a370d04cbb4b2ea88c7ea9e

commit_message:
[k8s] Cluster creation speedup

- Start workers as soon as the master VM is created, rather than
  waiting all the services ready.
- Move all the SoftwareDeployment outside of kubemaster stack.
- Tweak the scripts in SoftwareDeployment so that they can be combined
  into a single script.

Story: 2004573
Task: 28347
Change-Id: Ie48861253615c8f60b34a2c1e9ad6b91d3ae685e
Co-Authored-By: Lingxian Kong <anlin.kong@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit cae7fa21b63d471bb5bbc878fee68cace7a7d4a6)

subject: Set Content-Type header explictly for LegacyJsonAdapter
messages:
[{'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-15 04:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-15 11:51:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The request accepts JSON content as a response but the request body itself may not always be JSON, so I do not think it's appropriate to set it unconditionally.

You can pass headers to the adapter to set content-type yourself from the calling library."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-15 12:31:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Are we sure that's intent? I guess the request body (if there) is expected to be json as well."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-15 12:36:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Are we sure that's intent? I guess the request body (if there) is
 > expected to be json as well.

This is a generic request adapter, in my opinion we can't assume anything about the request body, only about the response body. The request may not even have a body, in which case the RFC you quoted isn't applicable."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-15 12:50:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> in my opinion we can't assume anything about the request body, only about the response body.

Well, I don't see where it's mentioned that have set Content-Type when using this or any client library doing it.

That leaves it to the recipient to guess the media type most cases which is not inline with the RFC.

Can you also help cite an openstack api example where the request body (if there) won't be json?"}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-15 12:54:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Though IMO we should change it here or at least document it, we already have a patch in heat ihttps://review.openstack.org/#/c/643504/'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-15 14:06:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > in my opinion we can't assume anything about the request body,
 > only about the response body.
 > 
 > Well, I don't see where it's mentioned that have set Content-Type
 > when using this or any client library doing it.

It's not mentioned because you don't always have to.

 > 
 > That leaves it to the recipient to guess the media type most cases
 > which is not inline with the RFC.
 > 
 > Can you also help cite an openstack api example where the request
 > body (if there) won't be json?

OpenStack examples: see the Swift API.

But keystoneauth is not just used for OpenStack APIs, this library for example supports authenticating with SAML2 or ADFS and in those cases uses other content-types.

Sure, probably in almost all cases, if you have Accept: application/json and you are also sending data, you should set Content-Type: application/json. But that's not guaranteed, and it would be incorrect to set Content-Type for GET or DELETE requests where there is no content."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-18 03:47:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> OpenStack examples: see the Swift API.

Swift response content-type is text/html(blob) in most cases. So I'm not sure they can use this at all.

> it would be incorrect to set Content-Type for GET or DELETE requests where there is no content.

AAFAIK, setting content-type when there is no body in the request does not really matter and would be ignored by recipients . 

Though there can be a check for the http method before setting content-type, I don't really care. 

We should surely move away from using LegacyJsonAdapter in heat asap."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-18 03:47:45.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-15 04:21:21.000000000', 'message': 'Set Content-Type header explictly for LegacyJsonAdapter

SessionClient in most services subclass LegacyJsonAdapter.
We don't seem to set the Content-Type header explicitly and
it can result in decoding issues.

From RFC2616:

Any HTTP/1.1 message containing an entity-body SHOULD include a
Content-Type header field defining the media type of that body. If
and only if the media type is not given by a Content-Type field, the
recipient MAY attempt to guess the media type via inspection of its
content and/or the name extension(s) of the URI used to identify the
resource. If the media type remains unknown, the recipient SHOULD
treat it as type "application/octet-stream".

Change-Id: I0f3849d1c741aeaf9880984157dc73a13bbc9fab
Story: 2005237
'}]
commit_message:
Set Content-Type header explictly for LegacyJsonAdapter

SessionClient in most services subclass LegacyJsonAdapter.
We don't seem to set the Content-Type header explicitly and
it can result in decoding issues.

From RFC2616:

Any HTTP/1.1 message containing an entity-body SHOULD include a
Content-Type header field defining the media type of that body. If
and only if the media type is not given by a Content-Type field, the
recipient MAY attempt to guess the media type via inspection of its
content and/or the name extension(s) of the URI used to identify the
resource. If the media type remains unknown, the recipient SHOULD
treat it as type "application/octet-stream".

Change-Id: I0f3849d1c741aeaf9880984157dc73a13bbc9fab
Story: 2005237

subject: optimize snmp_service
messages:
[{'account_id': 29383, 'date': '2019-03-14 12:41:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2019-03-14 13:01:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

The SNMP service was written by a developer that is no longer contributing to Vitrage, and I don't think that there is anyone else who is familiar with this code these days. In addition, there are no tempest tests for it (probably because it's complicated to write tests that involve SNMP traps). 

Did you manually check the SNMP service, and verified that it works with your changes? if so, I'll be happy to have a new contributor that takes over this code :-) but if not, it feels too risky to approve these changes."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-03-14 14:28:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Small refactor for create nonlocal user

This change refactors the local user attribute key deletion
when creating a new nonlocal user to simply pop the specific keys
instead of creating a separate list and iterating over it in order
to accomplish the same result.

Based on this[0] previous comment.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/357979/4/keystone/identity/shadow_backends/sql.py

Change-Id: Ice8c08d192f6eea84a6a05975177be026b1e8929

commit_message:
Handle image_volume_cache_enabled for PureStorage backend

Allows image_volume_cache_enabled to be set in the PureStorage
backend. This parameter will default to true if not set explicitly.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-27 05:57:56.000000000', 'message': "Use master upper-constraints when installing tempest plugins

when tempst venv is build, it use the master upper_contraint[1]
but when we install tempest plugin, it use branch upper_contraint.

This leads to mismatch the dependency version between tempest and required
tempest plugins setup.

Current flow after this change is:

1. install tempest form master (until you explicitly change TEMPEST_BRANCH
   which is default to master in all stable branch). It applies the upper_constraint
   from the stable branch but that will be overridden in step2
2. configure tempest, here the created venv will install all dependency with
   master's upper_constraint.
3. install tempest plugins in same venv created above. Now tempest plugin
   will also use the master upper_constraint.

With this tempest venv which has all enabled plugin will be contsraint with
master.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/72f632222f6d90d3545b5d7ca48297da4218e2ea/lib/tempest#L590
Closes-Bug: #1816022

Change-Id: I16f6121cf1f298a173ca23935ba35a7db7338516
"}]
commit_message:
Use master upper-constraints when installing tempest plugins

when tempst venv is build, it use the master upper_contraint[1]
but when we install tempest plugin, it use branch upper_contraint.

This leads to mismatch the dependency version between tempest and required
tempest plugins setup.

Current flow after this change is:

1. install tempest form master (until you explicitly change TEMPEST_BRANCH
   which is default to master in all stable branch). It applies the upper_constraint
   from the stable branch but that will be overridden in step2
2. configure tempest, here the created venv will install all dependency with
   master's upper_constraint.
3. install tempest plugins in same venv created above. Now tempest plugin
   will also use the master upper_constraint.

With this tempest venv which has all enabled plugin will be contsraint with
master.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/72f632222f6d90d3545b5d7ca48297da4218e2ea/lib/tempest#L590
Closes-Bug: #1816022

Change-Id: I16f6121cf1f298a173ca23935ba35a7db7338516

commit_message:
Adding create member role during the installation

When I installed devstack,I encountered a
"No role with a name or ID of 'member'." error.
After reviewing the scripts of the installation
process,I found that during the deployment of
keystone,the creation of the member role was
really missing,so I modified it with reference
to the Queen version.

Change-Id: I5d589fd874a64fa9884e35cddc2b14a033fd1747

gengchc2, this is the first step for bionic to install the correct version of jdk. Next will be doing what you're just saying. gengchc2, could you please point out for me what is wrong with elasticsearch in bionic. What surprises me is if freezer does not work properly with the same version of elasticsearch in bionic, why the tests passes?'}, {'account_id': 22484, 'date': '2019-03-15 09:18:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> gengchc2, could you please point out for me what is wrong with
 > elasticsearch in bionic. What surprises me is if freezer does not
 > work properly with the same version of elasticsearch in bionic, why
 > the tests passes?

Because of the difference between the new version and the old version of elasticsearch, there is a problem in the freezer-api search code .
Let's build another environmentto test it."}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2019-03-15 13:14:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

No, the elasticsearch version is the same. Only the OS platforms are different (xenial vs bionic). This patch only change the jdk version so it can be installed in bionic.'}, {'account_id': 22484, 'date': '2019-03-18 01:28:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> No, the elasticsearch version is the same. Only the OS platforms
 > are different (xenial vs bionic). This patch only change the jdk
 > version so it can be installed in bionic.

Ok. If the ES version is same, there is no problem. We used to install ES on bonic, but the current version can't be installed, so we upgraded the ES version."}]

- Pin tornade version less than 6.0.
  Currently, monasca-analytics use asynchronous decorator in tornade.web.
  But this decorator has been removed in tornade version 6.0.
  Therefore, openstack-tox-py35 in Zuul check is failed.

'}]
commit_message:
Update requirements for "tornade"

- Pin tornade version less than 6.0.
  Currently, monasca-analytics use asynchronous decorator in tornade.web.
  But this decorator has been removed in tornade version 6.0.
  Therefore, openstack-tox-py35 in Zuul check is failed.

This is tentative approach. tornade should be replaced to flask in near future.

Change-Id: I5e2e310c17b1dcdd4ab8e71c37f4f59104e2e63e

[{'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-02-19 14:24:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-02-19 14:49:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-02-20 14:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-02-21 16:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-02-22 09:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-22 16:25:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

There are 2 errors in the validation output:

 deliverables/queens/instack-undercloud.yaml: validate_release_type: openstack-infra/project-config/zuul.d/projects.yaml no release job specified for openstack/instack-undercloud, one of ['publish-to-pypi'] needs to be included in ['puppet-openstack-check-jobs', 'tripleo-undercloud-jobs', 'tripleo-multinode-baremetal-minimal', 'tripleo-multinode-container-minimal', 'openstack-python-jobs', 'openstack-python35-jobs', 'check-requirements', 'release-notes-jobs'] or no release will be published

 deliverables/queens/tripleo-image-elements.yaml: validate_pypi_readme: README check for openstack/tripleo-image-elements failed: Command '['python3', 'setup.py', 'check', '--restructuredtext', '--strict']' returned non-zero exit status 1"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-02-27 17:42:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I will ping on the triple O channel :)'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-02-28 12:57:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm not sure what to do with instack-undercloud. It was deprecated upstream, but still needs a release in queens. Emilien tried to set the release type in project-config [1], but it seems it wasn't the way to go. Any advice here?

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638459/"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-02-28 14:13:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'll add it to the agenda of the release team meeting for discussion"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-02-28 16:42:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Should be ok once https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638459/ is in'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-02-28 21:11:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-07 10:19:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Remaining error is:

deliverables/queens/tripleo-image-elements.yaml: validate_pypi_readme: README check for openstack/tripleo-image-elements failed: Unexpected indentation. (line 65)

It needs the following to be backported to stable/queens:

https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/README.md?id=2ac38dd68c6ff77ae95d3247316ff251e56a55bc

otherwise PyPI will just reject the upload and the release will fail.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-03-11 08:01:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I am unable to address this since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/640023/ can't merge. I haven't been able to fix nor even reproduce locally the issue."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-14 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I guess the issue here is that you want to release something that is no longer testable (or at least for which the tests are broken). If you are confident that (1) it's actually working and (2) you won't need to land any other change there in the future, you could disable the failing unit tests on that Queens branch, and land that README change..."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-03-17 22:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-03-17 22:55:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-03-17 22:57:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

PS 5 just addresses the 'validate' failure by updating the SHA for tripeo-image-elements to include:

 [tony@thor tripleo-image-elements]$ git lol 0498b94eb7ef64f785e0fb4f375acd5f035348f5..ed57f2eb8232e383ea4b8e7389e5c635f9816c94
 * ed57f2eb (origin/stable/queens, gerrit/stable/queens) (queens only) Fix identation in README so we can do a release
 * ae6e910a Add python jobs to tripleo-image-elements"}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-03-18 00:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
better handle empty notification confs

In some cases we do want to disable notifications a little more
selectively, but we should also log that we've done that in case
someone does so by accident and needs to debug.

Change-Id: I68dbf16002b9105df280261ff14de6299fe5aa78

messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-27 13:23:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2019-02-13 09:33:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28935, 'date': '2019-02-14 09:45:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28543, 'date': '2019-03-13 03:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-17 23:01:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Currently this library has no unit tests so this doesn't matter too much, but will merge for completeness sake.

The library part will soon be deprecated in favour of adding support to the SDK, and the CLI part will likely be rewritten anyway."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-27 13:23:37.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I93adb1f95f751f7db6b6aa01ceeeb329035c2676
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

commit_message:
Fix some py3 issues and a user invite cancel bug

old py3 issues on print, and some bad logic handling for canceling
a user invite when using the user (task) id.

commit_message:
Update v3 identity inherits tests to work w/ pre-prov

I don't see any limitations by using pre-provisioned credentials
for the tests:

* test_inherit_assign_list_check_revoke_roles_on_domains_group
* test_inherit_assign_check_revoke_roles_on_projects_group
* test_inherit_assign_list_check_revoke_roles_on_domains_user
* test_inherit_assign_list_check_revoke_roles_on_domains_group
* test_inherit_assign_check_revoke_roles_on_projects_user
* test_inherit_assign_list_revoke_user_roles_on_domain
* test_inherit_assign_list_revoke_user_roles_on_project_tree

By setting force_tenant_isolation=False these tests now be
can executed with backends that don't allow user creation
(immutable user source) like LDAP.

Partial-Bug: #1714277

Change-Id: I6b7bfbaef3355afede2adba56f342d5bfcbe3975
